content.desc: An Algerian man has died in an immigration detention centre in London. content.desc: Normally, an opposition could enjoy a week like the one that’s coming. It could sit back, relax and break open the popcorn as Theresa May walks into a Commons defeat on the policy that has defined her premiership. It could delight in yet more days of debate in which next to no one on the prime minister’s own benches rises to speak up for her, savouring the sight of a governing party that is devouring itself in full public view. content.desc: Homeless women in the UK are entering dangerous and abusive relationships in order to protect themselves from wider risks that come with living on the street, new research has found. A report by Brighton Women’s Centre and Homeless Link found the vulnerabilities faced by women who are sleeping rough often leads them to enter into relationships with men for protection – relationships which often expose them to abuse, violence, crime, drugs or sex work. content.desc: In happier times, Theresa May won positive “Maggie May” headlines in right-wing newspapers when they favourably compared her to Margaret Thatcher. content.desc: The British parliament's vote on Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal will go ahead as planned on Dec. 11, the leader of the House of Commons, Andrea Leadsom, said on Thursday. The odds look stacked against May's government winning the vote and The Times newspaper reported senior ministers were urging May to delay the vote out of concern that she risked a defeat so big it could bring down her government. content.desc: In the ancient democracy of Athens, executive positions were allocated by lot and held for a single day, so could it perhaps be the case that, two and half millennia later, the UK is not descending into chaos but rising to an altogether loftier ideal? content.title: As Brexit crunch nears, campaign for new referendum gathers pace - Reuters
content.desc: After losing the most contentious referendum in British history, James McGrory went for a drink in The Hope pub near London's medieval meat market. Amid butchers in bloodied coats, his dream of reversing Brexit seemed hopeless. content.desc: A cyclist dubbed Brighton's serial bottom slapper has been spared jailed after terrorising lone women in a spate of late-night attacks. But the judge at Hove Crown Court said the Romanian dish washer had escaped a prison sentence because he was so "severely intellectually impaired" that he would not cope behind bars. content.desc: Theresa May's plans to curb immigration after Brexit could result in businesses collapsing and jobs being lost, the head of the CBI has warned. content.title: Whatever his motives, Nigel Farage is right on Ukip - Financial Times
content.desc: More than anyone else, perhaps, Nigel Farage is responsible for Brexit. The former leader of the UK Independence party has devoted 20 years to stirring up anger against the EU by promoting falsehoods, twisting facts and stoking nativist — occasionally xenophobic — sentiments.
